description: From Middle English subverten, from Old French subvertir, from Latin subvertō (“to overthrow”, literally “to underturn, turn from beneath”).

verbs.description: subvert (third-person singular simple present subverts, present participle subverting, simple past and past participle subverted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To overturn from the foundation; to overthrow; to ruin utterly.
examples: This would be to subvert the principles and foundations of all knowledge.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pervert, as the mind, and turn it from the truth; to corrupt; to confound.
examples: A dictator stays in power only as long as he manages to subvert the will of his people.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To upturn convention from the foundation by undermining it (literally, to turn from beneath).

description: Back-formation from subvertising, by analogy with advert.
